input:

33:38 Caption: Toni Kroos (Real Madrid) sends in the corner, but fails to find the head of any of his teammates, allowing the defence to clear.

41:43 Event: Goal by Real Madrid
41:51 Caption: Goal! A mistake from the defence gifted a chance to a lurking Karim Benzema (Real Madrid), who keeps his cool and rolls the ball into the net from close range. 2:0.
42:50 Caption: Having seen unsporting behavior, David Fernandez Borbalan shows a yellow card to one of the players sitting on the bench. And Andre Gomes (Valencia) is the recipient.
44:04 Event: Kick-off by Valencia
46:13 Caption: The referee blows his whistle to end the first half and the players are now heading to their respective dressing rooms.
46:59 Caption: There was certainly plenty of action during that opening 45 minutes. The home side were more active and dominant in the first half. The opposition found it tough to keep up. The home team makes a lot of passes and attempts to maintain possession. The same goes for the away side.

Second Half:

12:58 Event: Goal by Real Madrid
13:21 Caption: Goal Cristiano Ronaldo (Real Madrid)! Cristiano Ronaldo (Real Madrid) was put through by James Rodriguez and he showed brilliant composure to tuck it home from inside the box. 3:1.

The ball bounces off his gloves and hits the post. Corner kick. Valencia will have an opportunity.

48:59 Caption: The players of both teams deserve praise from their managers and supporters for their performance on the pitch. If they carry on playing this exciting brand of football in future games, then the fans will surely be right behind them. There wasn't any significant dominance by either side in this game. The home team tried to find the weakness in the opposition's defence mostly using rapid counter-attacks, while the away team played possession football.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
The stage was set at the Santiago Bernabéu for a scintillating encounter between Real Madrid and Valencia, as both sides looked to put on a memorable performance. The whistle blew for the kick-off, and Valencia began the proceedings.

The game quickly found its rhythm as Real Madrid aimed to assert their dominance. However, the first few minutes were a scrappy affair, with the ball frequently going out of play and multiple throw-ins being executed by both teams. In fact, inside the first 10 minutes, there was an array of throw-ins and fouls, particularly by Valencia. Casemiro tried his luck from around 18 metres, but his effort whizzed just wide of the left post. Rodrigo presented Valencia's initial threat with a shot from inside the penalty area that fizzled into the stands.

Valencia's Enzo Perez found himself in the referee's book early on for a previous late challenge, a caution that was expected given his frequent fouling. Their determination to break Real Madrid’s strong hold was evident through the numerous fouls committed in quick succession. However, Real Madrid showed their attacking prowess when Cristiano Ronaldo managed to weave his way into a goal-scoring opportunity, only for the effort to be impressively saved by Diego Alves. But Ronaldo was not to be denied.

Just before the half-hour mark, Marcelo delivered a brilliant assist to Ronaldo, who found the net with a low drive into the bottom left corner, putting Real Madrid in front 1-0. Valencia's immediate response was a corner, but it was effectively dealt with by the Real Madrid defense. The match continued with end-to-end play, and throw-ins and corners peppered the first half. Karim Benzema was at the heart of Real Madrid’s attacking advancements but was unlucky on multiple occasions, with headers going narrowly wide or being saved by Diego Alves.

As the first half drew to a close, Real Madrid extended their lead to 2-0. Following a defensive error by Valencia, Benzema pounced on the mistake and neatly placed the ball into the net from close range. The referee soon blew the whistle to bring an eventful first half to a close. The scoreline certainly reflected Real Madrid's dominance, although Valencia had their moments and would look to bounce back in the second half.

Valencia made some significant changes during the break, bringing on Joao Cancelo and Santi Mina to freshen up their lineup. As Real Madrid kicked off the second half, they quickly aimed to press higher up the pitch. The script looked eerily similar with throw-ins and clearances being the order of the day during the early minutes. Real Madrid continued to press hard, and Diego Alves was called into action once again, making a critical save from Benzema’s header, a testament to his goalkeeping skills on the night.

An offside call against Cristiano Ronaldo briefly interrupted the game, but it did little to halt the momentum Real Madrid had built. Valencia responded with a few forays into the Real Madrid half and earned themselves a free kick from a promising position. Daniel Parejo stepped up and his fierce shot crashed against the crossbar—a narrow escape for Los Blancos.

Minutes later, Andre Gomes lined up a shot from 18 meters out, but Francisco Casilla denied Valencia with great agility. Valencia's persistence paid off as Rodrigo finally found the back of the net, reducing the deficit as he pounced on a rebound and put it past Casilla to make it 2-1.

Not wanting to rest on their laurels, Real Madrid hit back almost immediately. James Rodriguez provided a sublime through ball to Ronaldo, who showed his class by calmly slotting it home to make it 3-1. The game was now a thrilling contest with both teams looking to seize control.

Valencia’s Daniel Parejo latched onto a perfect pass and nearly scored with a daisy-cutter shot towards the bottom left corner, but Casilla once again rose to the occasion, pushing the ball onto the post and away. Valencia kept pushing, with a series of corners and shots that tested the Real Madrid defense, and Rodrigo came close again with a first-time strike that Casilla saved brilliantly.

Despite the two-goal cushion, Real Madrid did not ease the pressure. They brought on fresh legs, with Mateo Kovacic replacing Karim Benzema. The flow of the match continued with remarkable dynamism, punctuated by clearances, set pieces, and occasional fouls on both sides. Valencia’s ambitions took a hit when Rodrigo was shown a red card for unsporting behavior, reducing his side to ten men.

Real Madrid’s substitutions seemed to aid in maintaining their rhythm, Lucas being replaced by Jese. Valencia, even a man down, showed resilience and managed to score again. Andre Gomes received a brilliant pass and broke through the defense to fire it past Casilla, reducing Real Madrid's lead to a solitary goal at 3-2.

The final minutes were tense and packed with nerve-wracking moments. There was an anticipation of an equalizer, especially during the frantic last few exchanges. Valencia tried to make inroads, but time was not on their side. A peculiar incident occurred when Alvaro Arbeloa seemed to have netted another for Real Madrid, only for it to be disallowed due to a foul in the build-up.

In the end, the full-time whistle blew, bringing an end to an enthralling 90 minutes of football. Real Madrid emerged victorious with a 3-2 win, a scoreline reflecting a spirited fight back by Valencia but also showcasing the brilliance of Cristiano Ronaldo, who had managed a brace. Both teams deserved commendation for their efforts, providing fans with a match filled with goals, high stakes tension, and brilliant individual performances.

While Real Madrid employed their rapid counter-attacks to break down the opposition, Valencia’s game plan revolved around maintaining possession and working the ball through various channels. This contrasting style made for a compelling narrative and kept viewers on the edge of their seats till the final whistle. The high tempo, marked by frequent changes in possession, indicated the competitive spirit both teams brought to the pitch.

Ultimately, Real Madrid's slightly superior finishing and tactical execution secured them the victory and the valuable three points. A match that began with frenetic throw-ins and unsystematic play matured into a showcase of purposeful football, dotted with moments of sheer brilliance, especially from Ronaldo and key saves from both goalkeepers. The players’ efforts were rightly acknowledged by their managers and supporters, with each team showing glimpses of football that could keep the audiences enthralled in future fixtures. The harmony of Real Madrid's attack and the resilience of Valencia's tenacity were well portrayed in this classic encounter.
